5/ Still, Tim seemed optimistic that time and education could help turn the tech into a catalyst for change.

"Bottom line, there’s way too much hype, way too much publicity and not very many people who understand the ideas."

What's your favorite takeaway from Tim's piece?

4/ Tim wanted to see more innovation and big ideas, not crypto replacements for things we know today. 
 
"Remember, the excitement about bitcoin was mostly about bypassing controls, to enable exotic new uses like Silk Road. It was cool and edgy stuff, not just another PayPal."

3/ Tim believed there was a big risk the crypto industry would sell out its values.
 
"The tension between privacy (or anonymity) and know your customer approaches is a core issue. It’s decentralized, anarchic and peer-to-peer versus centralized, permissioned and back door.”

2/ Cryptocurrencies may be worth a lot, but May didn't think they – or the industry – are doing enough to reach real people in need or solve real problems.
 
"To date, cryptocurrency solves problems for few people, at least in the First World," he wrote.

RIP CYPHERPUNK LEGEND TIM C MAY

No-action letters may be a way forward for crypto startups hoping to avoid securities classifications. https://t.co/OcE9dodK32
"There are plenty of people trying to figure out how to do securities tokens. That's intereresting.... 'We're just going to own this.'" -- Szczepanik of the SEC.

"It's not the Hinman test. It's just the Howey test he's explaining the nuances around," SEC's Szczepanik says, on her colleague's speech from a few months back (the one where BTC and ETH were apparently cleared from being securities). #SECatWSBA
"It's the way that it's sold to you that makes it a security." -- SEC's Szczepanik. "What are the expectations around the offer and sale?" Not the key pair or the code. #SECatWSBA
No mention of word "utility" during this chat with SEC's Szczepanik, moderator @ronqman notes. #SECatWSBA
"It's a rare set of circumstances where you'd be deemed 'not a security' if you're raising money to capitalize a venture" -- SEC's Szczepanik on requests for no-action letters from token issuers.

What does it take to get a no-action letter from the SEC? Szczepanik: People coming to us with specific proposals. If comfortable we'll say: "Under these circumstances if you exactly this, staff won't recommend enforcement action."
"Not every jurisdiction has the same view of what a security is. Some have a constricted view, we have a very broad view." -- SEC's Szczepanik. Difficult to harmonize regulation. #SECatWSBA

SEC has CFTC and FinCEN on speed-dial. "It’s critically important, especially in emerging areas of law ... to have the regulators talking to each other so they’re getting each other's perspectives," says SEC's crypto/blockchain specialist Szczepanik.

Questions SEC considers re qualified custodians: Do you have exclusive control of private key? How do you audit for control of the key? How is key created? Multisig? Hot or cold wallet? How are you ensuring safety and soundness of client assets? -- SEC's Szczepanik #SECatWSBC
"To be a great regulator in this space you need to be able to listen to people," says SEC's Szczepanik. Re criticisms: "We want to hear that," welcomes people's input.
Opinion of commission on bitcoin ETF proposals does not hinge on how commission views bitcoin or blockchain or DLT, says SEC's Szczepanik. #SECatWSBC It's a nascent market, she notes.
"Anything said to you by a person selling it to you on YouTube, in white paper, on a website" can help determine if a token is an investment contract -- SEC's Szczepanik #SECatWSBA "It's a wrapper."
"Investment contract" (defined in Howey) is a broad, principles-based concept that makes it hard to draw bright lines. -- Szczepanik of the SEC #SECatWSBA

"I remember reading the white paper for the DAO and thinking 'if this ever is released into the wild, it's going to hit the SEC's front door in a big way.'" -- Valerie Szczepanik of the SEC #SECatWSBA

Valerie A. Szczepanik of the SEC reminisces about the investigation of early BTC ponzi schemer Trendon Shavers. "I think this was the first time anyone had associated Howey with something [crypto] related." #SECatWSBA
Fireside chat with Valerie A. Szczepanik of the SEC is about to begin. The moderator is @ronqman of @WallStreetBTC. #SECatWSBA
Valerie A. Szczepanik, the SEC's Senior Advisor for Digital Assets and Innovation, is speaking shortly at #SECatWSBA, hosted by @WallStreetBTC. We will be live-tweeting. Stay tuned.

@Coindesk_CEO : “We are honored to co-host #BlockchainWeekNYC. This annual week of conferences, events, meetups and gatherings - formal and informal - and of course our #Consensus2019 are all vital to the growth of the industry." Register: https://t.co/quVlTB7ntE https://t.co/9ZdhZPLZRG

On bitcoin ETFs, Clayton notes market manipulation concerns, asset custody:
"The risk in the ETF is truly the risk in the underlying asset, it's not the risk of theft or disappearance." #ConsensusInvest
Clayton: "People should understand that this was the remedy in this particular case but remedies in future cases may be different. Get your act together." #ConsensusInvest
Clayton explained that both companies offered unregistered securities #ConsensusInvest
Hutchins asks about a pair of recent SEC orders, where charges were settled with Airfox and Paragon. Clayton notes that the companies are providing rescission #ConsensusInvest
Clayton: "We are open to people coming into see us with their particular situation and I will tell you, some of these questions [take time]." #ConsensusInvest
Glenn Hutchins says one question the audience is interested in is "what is XRP." #ConsensusInvest
In particular that last line applies to when tokens are being sold to raise funding #ConsensusInvest

"We are happy to engage with people in this space ... if people have questions, they or their lawyers can come to us. But I have to say, if you are starting a venture ... you should start with the assumption that you're conducting a securities offering."- Clayton #ConsensusInvest
On when a token is decentralized, Clayton notes "When a store of value becomes truly decentralized, there's no one person controlling supply or trading." #ConsensusInvest
The other aspect revolves around exchanges - if there is open public trading the exchange must register or file for an exemption, Clayton says #ConsensusInvest

Based on the securities laws drafted in the 1930s, Clayton says an asset is a security when "I as an investor give you my money with the expectation of a return based on your effort." #ConsensusInvest
Glenn Hutchins: "Let's talk about when digital assets can act as securities." #ConsensusInvest
Clayton: "[Bitcoin] is different from [the] dollar or yen or euro because it's not sovereign-backed .... and it's not a liability of the bank." #ConsensusInvest
Regarding broker-dealers and other entities working with bitcoin, "we expect them to treat that as if they were accepting cash," Clayton says #ConsensusInvest

2/ " ... an asset like bitcoin, where decentralized, no one is creating it for their own control of bitcoin, it's designed to be a payment system replacement, we've determined that that doesn't have the attributes of a security." #ConsensusInvest
1/ Clayton: "We've all looked at sovereign currencies, the dollar, yen, those definitions are principles-based definitions." #ConsensusInvest
Clayton says the SEC is looking at how it may improve its oversight of the space without losing investor protection. #ConsensusInvest
As examples, Clayton cites shipping and "countless other places where a verified record is something that we spent a lot of money making sure we have and the efficiencies we have." #ConsensusInvest

@hutchins_glenn @SEC_News Clayton on distributed ledger tech: "This technology has incredible promise in the infrastructure, I think it has incredible promise beyond our securities markets." #ConsensusInvest

Following a question about using blockchain in the energy sector, the hearing officially adjourned. Story to come #CryptoCongress
.@valkenburgh also asked: "I would be interested in knowing how you can use something that isn't money to evade taxes" in his response to Roubini #CryptoCongress

.@Nouriel says cryptocurrencies' anonymity allows for crimes to happen, to which @valkenburgh notes: "It's not anonymous at all ... several law enforcement officials and investigators who enjoy doing blockchain investigations because you can track [activities]." #CryptoCongress

.@SenCortezMasto asks if there's a procedure for identifying crimes such as sex trafficking on the bitcoin network.
@valkenburgh notes that bitcoin is a protocol, so it's up to the businesses building on the blockchain to implement such procedures. #CryptoCongress
.@ChrisVanHollen segues into a few questions about the economy over the near future #CryptoCongress

In response to a question about a real-time payment system by @ChrisVanHollen, @Nouriel notes that the Federal Reserve can implement a number of systems to support one without using blockchain #CryptoCongress
.@valkenburgh: "Securities laws have worked well for the last 100 years or [nearly]." #CryptoCongress
.@SenWarren asks about regulating ICOs as securities offerings; @valkenburgh: "I agree with that approach."
.@Nouriel earlier referenced the "trilemma," though @valkenburgh notes that the triple-challenge "is not impossible, just something to strive toward." #CryptoCongress

.@SenToomey asks if the 5 transactions per second on the bitcoin blockchain is a hard limit. @valkenburgh notes that there are scaling technologies in testing right now, such as the Lightning Network. #CryptoCongress

In contrast, @Nouriel says "cryptocurrencies ... are being used by criminals, by terrorists, by tax evasors." Quotes Steve Mnuchin's line about not letting bitcoin being the new "Swiss bank account." #CryptoCongress

Asked about potential criminal use, @valkenburgh notes the bitcoin ledger keeps a record of every transaction, making it easier to ID: "We have phenomenal law enforcement in this country who … have become extremely adept at finding and deanonymizing the data." #CryptoCongress

.@senjohnkennedy asks @Nouriel if he sees any potential for blockchain as a technology.

Roubini responds that corporation cannot use public, trustless ledgers, and reiterates his point that most blockchain platforms dependent on mining are centralized at present #CryptoCongress

Sherod Brown: "It’s one thing for tech billionaires or the Winklevoss twins to invest, but I’m concerned about families losing their savings."
@valkenburgh notes that most investors must be at least technologically sophisticated due to the nature of crypto. #CryptoCongress
.@MikeCrapo's first questions were about volatility in the crypto markets and use cases #CryptoCongress
143 million* people https://t.co/67xOJT9fvo

.@BillClinton advised that people generally should "not get so carried away with the immediate financial rewards … if things sound too good to be true they often are." #SwellbyRipple

Regarding blockchain, @BillClinton says, "There needs to be an intelligent effort to identify the downsides. With the blockchain or whatever you don’t want money laundering, you don’t want … scams. You end up killing the goose that laid the golden egg." #SwellbyRipple

"The more you develop new technologies like blockchain … AI technologies, robotic technologies … the more the disparity of access is going to be felt," @BillClinton says, referencing differences in people's ability to access the internet at @SwellbyRipple

.@BillClinton: "The principles are the same: you want access and opportunity and protection from things that individuals in the private sector can’t protect themselves from on their own." #SwellbyRipple

.@BillClinton: "The more advanced economies become dependent on sophisticated information, the more they need to improve their defensive capabilities as well as their offensive capabilities." #SwellbyRipple

.@random_walker Narayanan says blockchain energy usage worldwide is roughly 5 gigawatts, somewhat more than Henly and Golden’s estimates earlier. #CryptoCongress
@ClaireHenly from @energywebx: "Bitcoin’s energy use is a substantial concern. We know that bitcoin’s energy use will prevent it from being able to scale. #CryptoCongress

Thomas Golden @EPRINews on bitcoin energy usage worldwide: "Today, worldwide bitcoin energy usage is estimated to be 2 to 3 gigawatts. This is less than 0.1 percent of the global power usage." #CryptoCongress

#CryptoCongress is officially adjourned for today but given that "cryptocurrencies will continue to have a greater and greater impact on our financial system," Chairman @RepAndyBarr imagines they'll be revisiting the topic again.

Garratt: Why does bitcoin have any value at all? ... For a currency to have value it simply needs to be the case that you will accept it from someone and someone will accept it from you. #CryptoCongress
One of the "great mysteries" of the @federalreserve according to Pollock is how dollar prices stay consistent in spite of "perpetual inflation." #CryptoCongress

Answering for the benefits of cryptocurrencies, @EswarSPrasad explains "there are many inefficiencies that lurk in the financial systems,"pointing out the "payments system" in particular where crypto could "make transactions much easier...and bring down the cost."#CryptoCongress

Further adding that cryptocurrencies "seems to be a solution looking for a problem...I can be in the smallest hamlet in rural India and use my Visa card. I’ve never had a problem paying someone." @BradSherman #CryptoCongress
@BradSherman wary of the "unparalleled advantages" cryptocurrencies offer to countries looking to evade U.S. sanctions and to people looking to evade taxes.  #CryptoCongress
Just because criminals have used #bitcoin doesn't mean it should be criminalized according to @norbertjmichel, testifying at today's @FinancialCmte #CryptoCongress hearing
Congressman Bill Foster: So the promise of blockchain is a non-falsifiable ledger … [what] remains an unsolved problem in the digital world is how do you authenticate yourself? #CryptoCongress

When asked by Chairman Barr whether bitcoin volatility would decline based on adoption rate, Garratt and @norbertjmichel responded with a resounding “yes.” Michel adding that, “The way bitcoin is set up has a lot do with its own volatility.” #CryptoCongress

@norbertjmichel warns that one of the “downsides” to the U.S. dollar being the world’s reserve currency as possessing the ability to "continue the fiction of thinking we can print as much as we want.” #CryptoCongress
Alex Pollock, Senior Fellow @RSI, thinks a central bank digital currency is “a terrible idea - one of the worst financial ideas of recent times.” #CryptoCongress

@EswarSPrasad says, "If in fact, where both the retail payments system and wholesale system were managed by distributed ledger systems...the private sector might do far more efficiently than government," but adding that the concern here is a matter of “trust.” #CryptoCongress
@norbertjmichel: Centralizing a cryptocurrency at a central bank provides no advantage over a traditional electronic database. #CryptoCongress

Garratt further notes, "The peer to peer aspect of cryptocurrencies could allow central banks to provide anonymity properties similar to those of cash." Nevertheless, "the potential for illegal behaviour is not unequivocally increased by cryptocurrencies." #CryptoCongress

Rodney Garratt, Professor at @UCSantabarbara, explains in his opening statements that, “The adoption rate of bitcoin will depend not only on its performance as a money, but also on the alternative forms of digital money that the central bank provides.”#CryptoCongress
And ICYMI California Rep. Brad Sherman stated in a previous @financialcmte hearing cryptocurrencies were a “crock.” Read more at: https://t.co/aZVi51n7hq
“We should prohibit U.S. persons from buying or mining cryptocurrencies,” says Congressman @BradSherman #CryptoCongress

Congressman Bill Foster adds: I hope to hear not only about cryptocurrencies … but also digital fiat currencies. I am concerned that if a central bank had the ability to issue a digital currency, it could supplant the dollar around the world. #CryptoCongress

@RepAndyBarr kicks off hearing and asks, "Are cryptocurrencies simply a new way to hold and transfer value that have a limited impact and niche appeal or will they have a far-reaching, transformative effect?"

HAPPENING NOW: The @financialcmte is hosting a hearing on whether cryptocurrencies are money in T-15 minutes.

Follow along at #CryptoCongress as CoinDesk reporters continue to provide full coverage of the event.

SOON: The second of two Congressional hearings on cryptocurrency begins at 2 p.m., when @financialcmte takes on the subject of whether cryptocurrencies are money.

Follow #CryptoCongress for CoinDesk's ongoing coverage.
Mining Malware Now a Bigger Threat than Ransomware, Says Report https://t.co/ESfWlPVrVC https://t.co/4ZfKR8SQKd
In his closing statement, Committee Chairman Mike Conaway notes that "As long as the stupid criminals keep using bitcoin it'll be great." #CryptoCongress
We are hiring a software engineer. #jobs #career https://t.co/EdJiUdydFB https://t.co/k5U1E9KmSX
.@JoshFairfield: "The way we catch criminals is through traffic analysis. Blockchains are quite good for traffic analysis." #CryptoCongress

Gensler: "Bitcoin is more traceable than the public thinks. We need a way to connect public keys to real people and real companies, and that's why I've recommended gateways to do that." #CryptoCongress
Rep. Stacey Plaskett asks how law enforcement can deter criminals from using bitcoin or other cryptocurrencies." #CryptoCongress
.@LowellDNess responded by saying the technology is still new, and "we're in the early stages of this." #CryptoCongress
Rep. Doug LaMalfa notes that he's "a flip phone guy in a bitcoin world," before asking what it might look like if cryptocurrencies are classified as securities. #CryptoCongress
.@LowellDNess: "The alleged Russian hackers were caught because they used bitcoin." #CryptoCongress  (ICYMI: https://t.co/woRvMnY88o)
.@skupor, in response to a question about halting money laundering through bitcoin: "Bitcoin is actually the worst tool to money launder because every transaction can be traced." #CryptoCongress
.@AmberBaldet: Cryptocurrencies "can act as a bridge" for people in distressed economies." #CryptoCongress

Gensler: "I could see even in stable economies like ours having a little bit of competition for the payment system. Startups and entrepreneurs have an opportunity to chip away at that, compete with that." #CryptoCongress

Gensler: "Sound governments have certain advantages I think because of the stability ... countries in distress, [the] Venezuelas of the world, this currency will be better for the public, for individual merchants." #CryptoCongress

Rep. Rick Allen: "We're creating another money supply here as I see it. I just don't know how that works. Our dollar sets the mark for the world. I can't visualize how this would work." #CryptoCongress

Gensler, speaking on decentralization: "Most economics, small economics, ends up with some centralization. The irony is that he technology is supposed to be decentralized and so it’s one of the natural ironies is that we all humans tend toward ... clusters." #CryptoCongress
Ethereum Client Parity Drops Wallet Tech in Major Upgrade https://t.co/2d6SSPwg2G https://t.co/rX8kNcWX4a
Rep. Ann Kuster says part of these funds could come from the IRS, which needs to "get on top" of how to properly tax gains in the crypto space. #CryptoCongress
.@DGorfine says the CFTC is looking to increase its resources to properly regulate the space: "[@giancarloCFTC] has been very vocal about this ... he's asked for $281 million." #CryptoCongress
.@DGorfine: "A lot of things are commodities. Soccer balls are commodities. Just because something is a commodity doesn't mean we have a direct [concern over it]." #CryptoCongress

.@LowellDNess: "It really comes down to the same test, pre-functionality versus post-functionality," adds that the difference in regulation would be whether a token is earned or bought. #CryptoCongress
Lucas: "Should method of delivery determine regulatory regime?" #CryptoCongress

.@skupor: "The issuance of those tokens ... is what I call an investment contract and should be regulated as such. No question about that there, but once tokens are functional ... the value is now about function, it's about the utility of the function." #CryptoCongress

Congressman Frank Lucas asks whether the way a token is distributed (meaning an ICO or token pre-sale) or the way the token functions (such as a bitcoin fork) should define how it is regulated. #CryptoCongress

In response, Gensler notes that "there's really nothing behind gold either ... what's behind it is a cultural norm, for thousands of years we liked gold. We do it as a store of value, so bitcoin is a modern form of digital gold. It's a social construct." #CryptoCongress
Ranking member Collin Peterson says much of the crypto space "seems like a Ponzi scheme," asking what backs the funds. #CrpytoCongress

.@skupor: "Utilizing a crypto network, you as the user own that data, you choose which date you want to expose to various advertisers and promote the flow of economic value [instead of an intermediary]." #CryptoCongress

.@AmberBaldet: Public blockchains can be thought of as a digital public commons, and usually also means open-source software "allowing auditing of the code [and] increasing trust in the code." #CryptoCongress
.@LowellDNess: "Create a set of bright lines that will enable the regulators to really know how to sort the good ones from the bad ones." #CryptoCongress
.@LowellDNess says "the threat of people going offshore for lack of clarity is a very real one," supports reasonable regulation. #CryptoCongress
Gensler: "There is a high failure rate for ICOs. One study in February of 2018 found that 59% of a sample of 2017 ICOs had already failed or semi-failed." #CryptoCongress

Gensler: "To date, 3,800 ICOs have launched and 200 crypto exchanges are operating with tens of millions of customers worldwide. About 55% of the crypto market value is now in tokens other than Bitcoin." #CryptoCongress

Former CFTC Chair Gary Gensler opens his testimony: "Though there are many technical and commercial challenges yet to overcome, I’m an
optimist and want to see this new technology succeed. It could lower costs, risks
and economic rents in the financial system." #CryptoCongress

LabCFTC head @DGorfine: "While some may seek the immediate establishment of bright lines ... hasty regulatory pronouncements are likely to miss the mark, have unintended consequences or fail to capture important nuance regarding the structure of new products.." #CryptoCongress

.@DGorfine: "One thing is certain - none of us are able to predict exactly where innovation is heading, and accordingly, it is incumbent on us ... to continue studying, learning and keeping pace with change." #CryptoCongress

LabCFTC director @DGorfine says "developments across [private and public blockchains] have society re-thinking the nature of money, how people transact, and how we can more efficiently engage in regulatory, economic, and market activity." #CryptoCongress

.@skupor is now opening his testimony: "Cryptonetworks enable a new way for innovative developers to create new digital services without the attendant risk of building on centralized platforms." #CryptoCongress

.@AmberBaldet: "The revolutionary proposition of cryptocurrency - or more broadly, cryptoassets - is the ability to send something you own across the internet and then irrefutably not have it anymore, without relying on a third party to intermediate." #CryptoCongress

.@AmberBaldet: "Email allows you to send a digital version of a birthday card to a grandchild instantly. Cryptocurrency like bitcoin gives you the ability to put the digital equivalent of $10 inside that card." #CryptoCongress

.@AmberBaldet is now making her opening statement, saying work in cryptocurrencies involve "technical research and development, corporate and financial industry transformation, digital privacy and public cryptocurrency advocacy." #CryptoCongress
.@JoshFairfield: "[Regulators] must not fail to recognize systems that walk, quack, and waddle like ducks merely because of some shiny new cryptocurrency feathers." #CryptoCongress
.@JoshFairfield "Token systems can and will reshape property law if they push price points low enough to unleash disruptive and scalable applications." #CryptoCongress
The first witness, @JoshFairfield, says cryptocurrency tokens represent "the future of property." #CryptoCongress
Ranking member Collin Peterson says he has some "real concerns" about crypto-related scams, noting that many ICOs result in investors losing their funds. #CryptoCongress
Conaway: "Providing a strong regulatory framework for [cryptocurrencies] is essential ... if it's necessary Congress or regulators might want to consider developing a new framework>" #CryptoCongress

House Agriculture Committee Chairman Mike Conaway opens the hearing: "While digital assets are thought of as payment systems, I believe the promise token networks hold is more universal and more reliable than that." #CryptoCongress

Voorhees vs Schiff: Bull Meets Bear at NY Bitcoin Debate https://t.co/UiXRtPm6hZ https://t.co/cqbIpf619L
Bitcoin's been through worse downturns than this, @qz reminds us https://t.co/PEBQnlXvUz https://t.co/kLeBjwVQFB

The audience was asked to vote on whether they saw bitcoin beating government fiat at the beginning and end of the debate: the yay votes rose from 40 to 55%, while the nay votes fell from 40 to 31% #VoorheesVsSchiff https://t.co/JHPgcNvRHs

.@PeterSchiff: “I think the crypto bubble will pop before the fiat bubble will, and in doing so I think it will succeed in doing something it shouldn’t, it will succeed in making fiat money look good.” #VoorheesVsSchiff https://t.co/vTi64LwTbV
.@PeterSchiff: “You can’t debase bitcoin because there’s nothing to debase. It has no value.” #VoorheesVsSchiff https://t.co/Kd31kFGlEu
.@ErikVoorhees: “With [gradual] adoption, bitcoin will come to replace fiat as the preferred medium of commerce.” #VoorheesVsSchiff https://t.co/Mkn9hjOgj8
In his closing statement, @ErikVoorhees says “every major government institution is studying this.” #VoorheesVsSchiff
.@ErikVoorhees: “The biggest obstacle to adoption is most individuals want governments to manage money for them. Until that changes, bitcoin will play second fiddle.” #VoorheesVsSchiff
.@PeterSchiff: “I think a lot of people are in crypto because they think they’re going to get rich.” #VoorheesVsSchiff https://t.co/94GebjIlK0
.@ErikVoorhees: “We need to get rid of this word, ‘faith.’ People aren’t in cryptocurrency because they have faith, they’re in it because they use it.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

.@PeterSchiff: “You have to concede that another cryptocurrency might replace bitcoin … and if another cryptocurrency can replace bitcoin, another cryptocurrency can replace that one.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

Asked what it would take to change his mind, @ErikVoorhees says “if something better than cryptocurrency happened...I think if there was a five-year period where the entire crypto market just slowly dwindled, I’d have to reassess.”#VoorheesVsSchiff
.@SkyCorridors asks @PeterSchiff if he would take a bitcoin vs. gold bet against @ErikVoorhees. #VoorheesVsSchiff

.@ErikVoorhees says:“I can send someone a billion dollars in bitcoin and the government [would not be able to stop this].”@PeterSchiff argues: "The problem is no bank is ever going to convert it, so the person you send bitcoin to is going to have to keep it.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

The debate enters a Q&A session.@ErikVoorhees: “Well, the government can absolutely outlaw bitcoin. More easily [than it would be to ban gold],” but adds that it would be hard to enforce.#VoorheesVsSchiff

@PeterSchiff cites the market decline seen over the last six months as an explanation on why the demand for bitcoin may decline: “You’ve destroyed your brand, once people sell at a loss they’re not coming back.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

.@PeterSchiff argues that gold is irreplaceable, but bitcoin isn't:“What’s the odds that bitcoin’s the best cryptocurrency that’s ever going to be invented? … Nobody’s come up with a better gold.” #VoorheesVsSchiff
.@PeterSchiff says intrinsic value refers to what someone can use with a form of money other than as a means of exchange. Gold has uses, but bitcoin does not have alternative uses. #VoorheesVsSchiff
.@ErikVoorhees continues:"I think this problem is self-correcting.” #VoorheesVsSchiff https://t.co/skmU9NVZk9

.@ErikVoorhees defends his stance, saying: “I remember when it was a big deal when bitcoin moved 50 percent. Today, it’s a big deal when it moves 10 percent. I think in a few years it’ll be a big deal when it moves 2-3 percent. While bitcoin is volatile today...
.@PeterSchiff adds: “It’s the same confidence that you have in the dollar or the euro, but the dollar, you have legal tender … but no one needs bitcoin.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

.@PeterSchiff concludes: “I think in the end, I agree with Erik completely that the fiat monetary system that we have now is not going to work, but replacing fiat currency with digital currency is not an improvement. What gives bitcoin value? Confidence.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

.@PeterSchiff, Euro Pacific Capital CEO, says “the biggest problem with bitcoin and why it can never be used as money is because it(currency) has to be a reliable store of value, not just a medium of exchange.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

.@PeterSchiff, Euro Pacific Capital CEO, argues “I’m not here to defend fiat currency, I think we’re headed for a currency crisis. I just don’t think bitcoin is going to succeed where the dollar had failed.”#VoorheesVsSchiff
@ErikVoorhees: “Your bank can destroy your fiat with the click of a button. With fiat, you are forever dependent on a third party for your wealth.” #VoorheesVsSchiff
@ErikVoorhees says bitcoin has a limited supply, is easily divisible, fungible and cross-border. These attributes mean it is “good money.” #VoorheesVsSchiff
@ErikVoorhees added: “Bitcoin possesses not only all the attributes of good money, but all the attributes of extremely good money.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

@ErikVoorhees, Shapeshift CEO, during The Soho Forum Debate:“I will construct my argument in four pieces: first, bitcoin is good money, second, fiat is bad money, third, why gold … is not good and fourth, why bitcoin will win.” #VoorheesVsSchiff

CoinDesk is at tonight’s @TheSohoForum debate on whether bitcoin will replace fiat currencies, featuring @ErikVoorhees and @PeterSchiff. Follow this space for live updates, beginning in 30 minutes. #VoorheesVsSchiff

@joe_rotunda @TxSSB @mjvasek The third panel - "Effective Approaches to Cryptocurrency Scams" - has begun at #cryptoscamsFTC.

@joe_rotunda @TxSSB .@mjvasek: "A lot of coins [were] introduced and then just abandoned [in 2015] ... We've seen in the last year a big resurgence of these coins" because pump-and-dump groups are taking advantage of the existing infrastructure to try and make funds #cryptoscamsFTC
@joe_rotunda @TxSSB .@joe_rotunda: "Regulators need to identify companies that are doing it right and they deserve a call, not a cease-and-desist." #cryptoscamsFTC
.@joe_rotunda from @TxSSB: "This is something that blew up last year, and as a result there are a lot of people who are at risk" #cryptoscamsFTC

.@joe_rotunda: "New markets, emerging markets and trending markets tend to attract bad actors." Notes that a lot of these bad actors tried to take advantage of the cryptocurrency price increases in 2017 #cryptoscamsFTC
.@Kyle_ish opens panel two by outlining different types of scams, including pump-and-dumps, some airdrops, phishing scams and exit scams. #cryptoscamsFTC
The next panel - "Examining Different Cryptocurrency Scams" - is starting now at the @FTC's #cryptoscamsFTC workshop.
@valkenburgh .@valkenburgh: "If you can't tell the wheat from the chaff, on what is techno-gibberish or actual innovation, you should not participate." #cryptoscamsFTC
.@valkenburgh: "If you yourself are not capable of explaining to somebody what a token's supposed to do, you should not buy the token." #cryptoscamsFTC
.@rumimorales on the difficulties with buying or selling tokens on exchanges: "It's amazing how centralized all this still is." #cryptoscamsFTC
.@valkenburgh: "We are still in the early days of this as a technology. You can think about how difficult the internet was to use in 1994." #cryptoscamsFTC

.@rumimorales is now speaking, explaining potential uses for cryptocurrencies: "If time is money," consumers should be compensated for the time they spend on sites like Facebook and Google. #cryptoscamsFTC
.@valkenburgh starts the first panel off with a description of bitcoin and cryptocurrencies, noting that there are differences: "they have different focuses or inspirations." #cryptoscamsFTC

Smith: "Indeed in just the first two months of 2018, consumers have lost $532 million. Consumers will lose more than $3 billion by the end of 2018." 
#cryptoscamsFTC

@FTC .@FTC Director of the Bureau of Consumer Protection Andrew Smith opens his remarks by noting that there are more than 1,600 cryptocurrencies in existence, with a market cap of $290 billion. #cryptoscamsFTC

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA @giancarloCFTC Moderator David McGill asks if allowing a jury to determine if a token is a security is the right approach, referring to a case that @SEC_News and the @TheJusticeDept brought against businessman Maksim Zaslavskiy (Read more: https://t.co/82ZjgSqNZG) #NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA @giancarloCFTC Oakland: "If there needs to be action ... if there needs to be rule making that's possible. I don't think it's going to stifle innovation, it's the nature that Congress has set up with their laws." #NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Oakland: "It can be daunting for a startup who has all kinds of things in their head to think 'is this a security?' One of the things @giancarloCFTC created [is] LabCFTC, for people to come to the @CFTC and talk." #NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Oakland: It is up to regulators to apply the laws that Congress has created. Notes that a "barrel of oil ... is a commodity. It's also a property. It also has environmental rules [so] it has all kinds of different issues." #NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Oakland: "Enforcement is a large hammer to try and shape rules to market participants. It's not something that is a useful tool to promulgating new rules to follow. It's an 'after-the-fact' mechanism." #NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Oakland: "We're focused on derivatives products. Anytime derivatives are going to be offered or embedded inside crypto assets, that's going to raise red flags for us." #NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA David Oakland, an attorney with @CFTC: "There's not a unified regulator for spot transactions. There's not a single body that can dictate for somebody who wants to operate a spot exchange for any of these cryptocurrencies unless they happen to be a security." #NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Cohen: "The other part of this ... is we're very concerned about fraud. There's a high risk of people victimized [by] fraud and we've seen that." 
#NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Cohen: "If you look at the economic realities of what [investors] are doing it's really important they follow the law and follow disclosure requirements."
#NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Cohen: "We're not looking to stifle innovation - we're mandated to encourage it."
#NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Cohen: "People are investing money in a common enterprise because someone has an idea for a business and you hope to make a profit. That's really a security."
#NYCrypto

@NYCBarAssnNews @SEC_News @CFTC @FINRA Robert Cohen, head of the SEC's cyber unit: "A really important issue for us is ... cryptocurrencies, digital assets [and] ICOs are clearly a high priority [for] the market and investors and therefore for us." #NYCrypto

.@msantoriESQ: "The HM Treasury publishes a global list of payment mechanisms used for crime, and they list every single payment mechanism and rank them … every year so far that virtual currencies have been included on the list, they have been ranked dead last." #CFRLive

@msantoriESQ @Jose_Pagliery .@Jose_Pagliery: "To access cryptocurrencies and use it you need to be able to access the network and use it. It's great for cybercriminals who want to get paid for ransomware ... but terrible for terrorists." #CFRLive

@msantoriESQ .@Jose_Pagliery on whether terrorist organizations are using cryptocurrencies: "I don't know ... I try to put myself in the shoes of someone who might benefit from this ... cryptocurrencies are such a terrible store of value that you'd be better off trading in oil." #CFRLive
.@msantoriESQ: The use of non-profit foundations for token projects to circumvent some financial regulations does not necessarily go well #CFRLive

@msantoriESQ @Jose_Pagliery @MariaTVullo .@MariaTVullo: "We need to do our best to manage the risk and at the same time allow something new to flourish, but the international nature of this and the technology is really what’s taking us [time] because some people are uncomfortable." #CFRLive #VulloOnCrypto

@msantoriESQ @Jose_Pagliery .@MariaTVullo: "Obviously we have some concerns about that." 
She says other, more traditional, financial companies might move to a location like the Cayman Islands for tax reasons, "but they do have a functioning government and oversight." #CFRLive #VulloOnCrypto
@msantoriESQ .@Jose_Pagliery: "I am concerned about companies that leave [countries] to avoid regulation." #CFRLive
@msantoriESQ In response to a question about crypto startups moving to nations with "friendly' laws, @msantoriESQ: "That's regulatory arbitrage. There's no hiding." #CFRLive
.@msantoriESQ: "I don't think cryptocurrencies need a stamp of legitimacy" from central banks. #CFRLive

@msantoriESQ .@msantoriESQ: "Different regulators look at this differently. I criticize U.S. regulators for moving too quickly, but to their credit, they are light-years ahead of other nations." #CFRLive

.@msantoriESQ notes that "the U.S. can export its laws around money through the G20 [but] it cannot export its laws around securities." Adds that a lot of the money pouring into ICOs are from professional investors in different countries - not casual American investors #CFRLive

@MariaTVullo .@Jose_Pagliery: "The question about whether or not accredited investor laws need to be looked at ... the law about whether you need a certain amount of wealth to invest, I think that's terribly unfair." #CFRLive
FOAM and the Dream to Map the World on Ethereum https://t.co/TYkXMssQVf https://t.co/VR67HC9GMa

On whether regulators need to revisit the assumptions around consumer protection, @MariaTVullo says "In all of these areas, with anything new, you have to look at whether the law is applicable or if you need to tweak it." #CFRLive #VulloOnCrypto

.@seemacnbc asks if different tokens can be separated into those used for criminal activity and those used for more legitimate purposes. 
@MariaTVullo: "I don't think you can separate those. There is clearly risk here." #CFRLive #VulloOnCrypto

.@msantoriESQ: "I think everything that can be tokenized will be tokenized ... I think tokens will make illiquid assets highly liquid. That comes with risks ... but it also has tremendous potential." #CFRLive
@MariaTVullo @Jose_Pagliery @msantoriESQ .@msantoriESQ says bitcoin's code is open-source: "There are people who look at it and point out bugs." #CFRLive

@MariaTVullo @Jose_Pagliery .@Jose_Pagliery: "What we've learned is that code is law, but coders have the power ... they have no responsibility toward you that I've seen by law ... we have to figure out how these people are held accountable." #CFRLive

@MariaTVullo .@Jose_Pagliery: "There's this idea in cryptocurrency that code is law, that the code is the rule, it's not going to change, you're not going to be affected by some central bank board changing the rules willy-nilly." #CFRLive

@MariaTVullo .@MariaTVullo: "I think regulators absolutely need to be in the space. I know [developers] are saying 'we're innovative, we're startups, we need to be left alone and put in a sandbox.' Toddlers play in the sandbox. Adults play by the rules." #CFRLive #VulloOnCrypto

On mining, @MariaTVullo says: "The amount of energy that is needed for the mining operations to support the blockchain … I also think the cost of the operations is something to think about when making the claim that this technology can assist with payment transmission." #CFRLive
@msantoriESQ @MariaTVullo .@msantoriESQ: "New York has become a crypto backwater," says he's spoken to clients who do not want to work in the state due to the #BitLicense #CFRLive

@msantoriESQ @MariaTVullo .@msantoriESQ: "I think ... those laws have been an abject failure," referring to the #BitLicense 
#CFRLive

@msantoriESQ .@MariaTVullo on differing state and federal regulations: "In many ways this is no different than other types of banking-related services where you have the state regulators, you have the public companies that are also regulated by the SEC ... the CFTC." #CFRLive #VulloOnCrypto
.@msantoriESQ: "I think the SEC has done the best job possible" in its efforts to regulate token sales #CFRLive
@msantoriESQ .@Jose_Pagliery: "What we’ve got today are ICOs or other projects where hundreds of thousands of people will lose millions of dollars and that damage has to be accounted for." #CFRLive

.@msantoriESQ: "I wouldn’t say that [ICOs] are tools for avoiding regulation. People who are running token sales are trying to do a lot of things, including raising money … it’s not just about avoiding regulations." #CFRLive
.@msantoriESQ on ICOs: " I think a lot of these token sales run afoul of the spirit of the law, if not the letter of the law. But we have to be careful not to lump them all together." #CFRLive

#CDXforum

@ejohn1 @hulu @admergency @FusionSeven @gilbeyda @garyjdavis .@gilbeyda: "It’s inconvenient if our identity is stolen, if our credit card is stolen, but we have mechanisms to recover that. If you have a public-private key pair, and you lose that, it’s gone … if you have a private key, you have access to all of the resources."
#CDXforum

#CDXForum

And with that, Abraham adjourns the meeting #BlockchainInTheHouse

White: "We haven't really seen this industry change since the 1950s and blockchain provides us an opportunity ... because I think the industry is ready for change."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@RepLoudermilk @RepDonBeyer @RepMcNerney Maughan: "I think you have a potential for service companies to provide - they exist in cryptocurrencies, you have bitcoin miners - who provide the infrastructure to run a blockchain."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@RepLoudermilk @RepDonBeyer @RepMcNerney .@RepMcNerney: "Can someone address the energy implications of blockchain and how can it be mitigated?" 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@RepLoudermilk @RepDonBeyer White: "I think coming together through these advisory boards ... is really important to come together on what standards to get alignment on."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@RepLoudermilk .@RepDonBeyer: "If you adopt blockchain will UPS drivers be allowed to turn left?"
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@RepLoudermilk Beyer asks about bitcoin's average transactions per second rate, but Rubio notes that it's a different network. 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

.@RepLoudermilk asks about consumer benefits.
Rubio: "By posting information in real-time to the supply chain data can be shared and that can streamline the flow of goods. The benefit to the consumer is they can receive their product sooner."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

.@RepLoudermilk: "If we can overlook the stigma of cryptocurrency and look at the technology beneath it I think we can see [some useful applications]," referring to blockchain as an "incredible technology."
#BlockchainInThe

White: "I think the US is right in the forefront of that," citing Maersk and IBM's work, as well as other pilot projects 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Beyer: "I believe America should take the lead in blockchain research," but notes other nations are publicly announcing research projects - 
"Where's the US?"
#BlockchainInTheHouse

In response to Rep. Don Beyer, Maughan notes that not every application needs a blockchain specifically - in some instances, a simple database will suffice. 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Rubio: "From our side it's about reducing friction in the supply chain ... as we can collect information in the real-time that can speed up supply chains and provide fast-moving product."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

White: "From a @MaerskLine perspective, some of what we see are global supply chains, which are some of the most complex today ... I think blockchain is especially suitable for that." 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Rep. Randy Hultgren asks what existing projects can benefit most from blockchain technology.
#BlockchainInTheHouse
JUST IN: Crypto Exchange Probe 'Continues' Despite New York AG's Resignation https://t.co/dhDWVmt7Zo https://t.co/1N7I296ion

Marshall: "Can we trace it backwards and find the origin?"
Rubio: "Yes."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@Maersk @IBM Rep. Roger Marshall: "How can blockchain ... any thoughts on how blockchain can impact [fentanyl theft and distribution]?"
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@Maersk @IBM Rep. Suzanne Bonamici asks if blockchain can be used to prevent prescription drugs from being stolen
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@Maersk @IBM Rubio: "[Blockchain] technology really lends itself to advancing intellectual property rights protection."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@Maersk @IBM White: "The ability to identify when any document has been changed … helps identify any risk of fraud much more easily."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@Maersk @IBM White: "If any of those documents changed, it’s immediately identifiable that that document has changed. That can go to a customs agency when that document is certified."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

White: "The platform we’re putting together between @Maersk and @IBM identifies the sources of information, so we use blockchain to establish who are [the originators]."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Chiaviello notes the impact counterfeiting is having on legitimate businesses, to which Abraham asks how blockchain can help. 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Abraham says blockchain technology may be as revolutionary as GPS. 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Rubio: "The international community must come together to create common standards for blockchain, to give it the confidence [to work effectively]."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Rubio: "In order for blockchain to reach its full potential, all products would have to be tagged, which would require an overhaul in the way the industry handles items."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Chris Rubio, vice president global customs brokerage staff @UPS: "By having the ability to track any product from the beginning of its journey through the supply chain, blockchain may provide a solution to unknown or unverified product origins."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

White: "This platform will give traders and transportation and logistics providers real-time end-to-end visibility and permissioned access to information about cargo shipments."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

White describes trialing a blockchain platform to track shipments: "The trust necessary to build this network would likely not exist without blockchain."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

White: "Everyone agrees that there must be a better way but no single participant can effect change … in 2016 Maersk and IBM began a collaboration with the goal of digitizing supply chain." 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Mike White, head of global trade digitization at Maersk begins his testimony by discussing the issues surrounding global shipping: "Container shipments can also be delayed because essential paperwork has not caught up with the goods they are carrying."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Robert Chiaviello, IPR counsel at Nuby Law: "I'm here to explain to the committee a growing problem that we are experiencing from unfair competition," referring to counterfeit goods created overseas. 
#BlockchainInTheHouse

@DHSgov Maughan: "DHS S&T must aggressively work with its research, development, test and evaluation partners throughout government and industry."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Douglas Maughan, cyber security division director of the Science and Technology Directorate at @DHSgov: "Blockchains offer promise" in both private and public sectors
#BlockchainInTheHouse

Congressman Ralph Abraham, who is chairing the hearing, is opening the talks: "We recognize [blockchain] technologies can benefit both the public and private sectors, and seek to understand just how."
#BlockchainInTheHouse

#Synchronize2018

Clayton says he is not concerned about regulations possibly forcing blockchain startups to move to other countries. 
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "We decided many years ago that a foreign entity selling securities in the US would be treated no differently than a US entity selling securities. That approach has served us well and I don’t think we should change it in light of new technology."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "What we find in the regulatory world, the use of a [utility] token evolves over time. The use can evolve toward or away from a security."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: It's "too early to tell" how capital in the cryptocurrency space will be allocated. 
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "[Exchange-traded funds] space is a retail space - we have a lot of retail protection, including asset validation ... in the crypto world, people are uncomfortable with it. How would you feel if the market could [fall] 30%? That's what happened on Friday."
#ClaytonCrypto

The nature and goals of cryptocurrencies has evolved over time, Clayton says: "It's been interesting to watch the evolution of crypto."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "I'm an engineer, I believe in the promise of tech. I hope we look back on this as an inflection point but I can’t tolerate fraud."
#ClaytonCrypto

He continues: "Because this technology is being used for fraud and to the extent that it’s being used for fraud, history shows that government comes down harshly on that technology later."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "Is the approach taken in Washington by the SEC adversely affecting distributive ledger tech in other areas? My quick answer is that my hope is that it’s actually helping."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "There was not an appetite to regulate currencies in the past ... this technology may have changed that."
#ClaytonCrypto
Clayton is now taking questions from the audience at Princeton University #ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "If there's a substitute currency, the ability to regulate monetary policy will be diminished." 
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "If you’re a government, you want a sovereign currency because you have control over the currency and the ability to look at flows and see what’s being produced and the ability to affect monetary policy." 
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "What I find much more interesting is the function that cryptocurrencies play ... they've been promoted as ... an efficient means of exchange."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "Our exchanges are set up to prohibit ... dumping shares or pumping the price. The exchanges where ICOs or bitcoins are traded don't have the same kind of regulation."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton compares cryptocurrency markets with traditional stock: "Common exchanges like the NYSE are not unregulated - they’re highly regulated - the types of orders you can place on exchanges and the types of exchanges you can engage in are highly restricted."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "I think if we don’t stop the fraudsters, there is a serious risk that the regulatory pendulum, the regulatory actions will be so severe that they will restrict the capacity of this new security."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "Does this mean that all ICOs are bad? Absolutely not."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton says the SEC will enforce regulatory actions against bad actors, citing last week's shutdown of Centra Tech: https://t.co/VWLIqvsdhS
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton notes that securities sales can go down a private placement route or as a public offering. Both have certain restrictions and limitations. 
#ClaytonCrypto
Malta Finance Regulator Warns Against Crypto Margin Trading Site https://t.co/bOa84JKgDB https://t.co/FBCtsUq0AM

Clayton: "The security standards that regulate stocks or coins are pretty simple in concept."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "We at the SEC have seen this and have made it clear that if you are offering something that depends on the efforts of others, it should be regulated as a security and that you should follow our regulations when you offer it."
#ClaytonCrypto https://t.co/MN9vBsZYy4

Clayton: "That has been a question because what has happened in the ICO space is people are offering these coins and tokens but they are trying to characterize them as something other than a security."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "I think that's right - when you are taking your money and giving it to somebody and saying 'go off and do something with this and I want a financial return for that,' that needs heightened regulation." 
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton has begun discussing ICOs and how the SEC is looking at them: "Almost every ICO - these are investments in endeavors where people are taking your money and doing something with it and promising a return. Those are on the stock side of the spectrum."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "Where do you go from a store of value that is not a security to a store of value that is a security?"
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton illustrates an example using bitcoin as one end of a spectrum, and stocks stored on a blockchain as the other: "The question is, where does our jurisdiction begin?"
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "How we approach securities transactions matters ... the way I divide the world is that we have a number of stores of value [related to] blockchain values." 
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "We regulate securities transactions, the offer and sale of securities. We don't regulate bank loans, transactions in cash ... this technology has touched significantly on securities."
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "Blockchain technology is being pursued by lots of people - what does it mean for us at the SEC?" 
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "Being able to move that quickly among people in a way that you’re confident that what you’re receiving is what you expect to receive is a fundamental element of how we've organized our banking markets." 
#ClaytonCrypto

Clayton: "I will start with my belief that distributed ledger technology has incredible promise for the financial industry that is transaction-based." 

#ClaytonCrypto

SEC Chairman Jay Clayton is about to discuss cryptocurrencies and ICOs at Princeton University. Follow @coindesk for live updates 
#ClaytonCrypto

Strong Words, Little Action: ICOs Draw Fire at US Congress Hearing https://t.co/6nXa0k4HKY https://t.co/MHNwGmYJCk
Correction: The "crock" statement was Rep. Sherman's own, he read it aloud after entering Rep. Maloney's written statement into the record. #ICOsInTheHouse https://t.co/eofkMgk0Zu

Huizenga wraps up the hearing: "I believe that this is probably hello and not goodbye."
Legislators will have five days to submit further written questions to the panelists. 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh "Yes ... it's not just anarchic between federal agencies potentially, it's anarchic between federal and state regulators."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Scott: "When you have several regulators involved, and several regulatory agencies, it puts your industry in a somewhat awkward position. Would you recommend that whatever we do, we put in a rule for harmonization?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer: "When it comes to the commodity/securities question, institutional competence is extremely important in thinking about who should be regulating different institutional product."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "Guidance from the SEC as to how they’ll interpret the Howey Test with respect to token sales ... further guidance might be helpful especially with respect to how you draw the line and it might look more like what Europe’s doing these days."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "The first thing I'd point out is this is a global technology."
#ICOsInTheHouse

North Carolina's Ted Budd: "Regulation in this space is something that the U.S. has to get right, because poor or rushed policy in cryptocurrencies really threatens our reputation in finance and technology."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "I think we want to look to the institutional competencies of these two different agencies to protect investors," referring to the SEC and CFTC.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Scott: "We’re dealing with an opportunity to get it right before we get it wrong."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Scott: "If they are registered with the SEC, should these digital wallets be subject to enhanced cybersecurity protocols?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Scott: "What are the benefits to investors in digital wallets to registering with the SEC?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Huizenga: "But that's a government-issued cryptocurrency," notes that it is not like a decentralized cryptocurrency.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: "Many governments are digitizing their currencies ... I think that is something that may very well happen."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Huizenga: "Will a governmental central bank in any system recognize and utilize a cryptocurrency?" 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer: "Digital things tend to be abstract and therefore tend to be more difficult to understand."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer: "There is a difference in how commodities are regulated under the Commodity Exchange Act and how securities are regulated ... and these are things that I think you as a committee ought to take into consideration."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: "I think that in the long run ... we shouldn't worry about the distinction 'this is a commodity, this is a security.'"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: When the tokens on the platform become less valuable than the platform, "it's probably no longer a security under Howey."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Sherman: "Perhaps we’ll have another hearing after a major terrorist event” that uses cryptocurrency.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Sherman: "Is there some kind of great social purpose that cannot be met in any other way?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: "Tokens can do things you can't with cash in a platform where you have buyers, sellers, third-parties who have important roles ... we're talking about a very different business model."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh notes that residents in other countries may find it difficult to access fiat currencies or banking services. 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "You and I have the benefit of a well-functioning financial infrastructure and most Americans find it not too difficult to become banked."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rep. Brad Sherman: “A currency is both a store of value... and a medium of exchange ... is there any reason why I would need a cryptocurrency to pay for my groceries or anything else that wouldn’t be adequately served by using dollars?”
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: Clearing up custody rules would be very helpful.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "These technologies cross borders so "compliance when done at a local level is very burdensome and often redundant."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Wagner: How does Coinbase coordinate with law enforcement?
Lempres: "We train more law enforcement agencies I believe than anyone ... and what I talk about training, it's how the blockchain works, it's how cryptocurrencies work."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "It was a very ambitious effort by the state to regulate in this space ... they have chilled activity in the state of New York."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Missouri Rep. Ann Wagner asks Lempres if the BitLicense is an appropriate model for other states.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: Trying to decide what's a security and what's a commodity "would lead the market to distraction."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Ohio Rep. Warren Davidson: "Can you talk a little bit about the concerns with respect to venture vs. ICOs?" 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum also notes that Foster's three questions are possible on regulated exchanges. 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: "I think when we move to something like bitcoin, there you have a much more difficult problem, because that genie is already way out of the bottle ... you can follow bitcoin throughout the trail, you just don’t know who has it."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "If you're trading on our platform ... we have your bank account ... so in many ways while it’s not a consolidated audit trail, we have much of that information gathered on our platform where we’re able to reconstitute it if it’s necessary."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Foster has three questions:
"Will there be a mechanism to bust trades?
Is there a need for something like a consolidated audit trail?
Will there be a mechanism to ... unveil the identity of counterparties and issuers?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Illinois Rep. Bill Foster begins his questions: "Much of our daily lives will soon involve blockchain."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "From our standpoint, what we need more than any particular approach is to know what that approach is going to be from the government."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Emmer: "To say 20 percent of your employees are working on compliance, that's nothing to celebrate."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Emmer: "Access to capital is something Democrats and Republicans should celebrate ... I recognize there has to be some regulation, but it's the balance."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Minnesota Rep. Tom Emmer: "I hear elected officials who don't have any concept of what we're dealing with here ... talking about 'we have to go in and regulate.'" 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer: I think [it] would be extremely helpful" to subject cryptocurrency exchanges to cybersecurity regulations.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer says Congress would need to expand the SEC's authority to regulate cryptocurrencies being traded as investments. 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Maloney says she is working on a bill to regulate cryptocurrencies as investments. 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "We have nearly 20 percent of our total employees [who] are dedicated toward compliance."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "We take that very seriously, specifically with regard to hate groups ... It is one of the nice things about [blockchain] technology - it actually gives you insight."
#ICOsInTheHouse

New York Rep. Carolyn Maloney to Lempres: "What are you doing to prevent extremists from using your exchange to fund their activities?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Stivers asks if FinCEN's 2013 guidance on AML/KYC safeguards are appropriate.
Van Valkenburgh: "I think it's a very sensible piece of guidance."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "We have a flexible test in the U.S. for what is a security, and it is derived from the Howey case," notes that ICOs are largely dependent on developers producing a project.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Ohio Rep. Steve Stivers begins asking questions: "Can you talk a little bit about the promise of blockchain technology to make our system more transparent ... efficient, and what blockchain can mean for financial transactions and other things in our economy?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "I think a lot of this looks like the dot-com bubble of the late 90s," but some of the projects are challenging multinational corporations. 
#ICOsInTheHouse
US Lawmaker Presses Treasury on Venezuela's Petro Sale https://t.co/VmxOQPJK5B https://t.co/1FLGJOihXf

Brummer on recent volatility: "I think it's a product of speculation ... it's a bubble, it's a product of ... investors chasing money, it's a product of inadequate disclosure." 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer: "It's not only that they can lose some of their money, they can lose all of it ... these are the kinds of risks that retail investors may not understand."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer: "I would certainly say given the complexity of many of these instruments that it's very dangerous."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Ellison: "If somebody who's not sophisticated in this area wants to invest, what should they know in advance?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "We have received some guidance ... for example the CFTC has specifically found and published a primer."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Hultgren: "How do you establish legal certainty for currencies you currently support?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "We do hold a little bit of fiat currencies - USD - those are held in banks ... as for cryptocurrencies, there is no federal insurance program." He adds that funds stored in hot wallets are insured, and that Coinbase has never been hacked.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "The cybersecurity standard we most adhere to is New York State's BitLicense. We're also working with a few of the Big Four accounting firms to develop appropriate standards."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Hultgren: "Is Coinbase subject to ... any other federal security laws?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "Our cybersecurity protocols are I believe state-of-the-art ... approximately 99 percent of the assets we hold are held offline ... which makes us virtually immune to a hack."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Hultgren: "What cybersecurity standards does Coinbase adhere to?"
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: "Regulation is important ... [but first] we do need more guidance on those areas."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: "Regulation by enforcement in an area that is as complicated and dynamic as this is not the appropriate way."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Scott: "What ... could the federal regulators could be doing better?" 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Scott: "Let me switch to the ICO issue ... I can assure you that none of us ... want to be killing good innovation, especially one that is raising billions of dollars of capital." 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Scott also notes that while there are regulations at the state level, "there are none at the federal level."
Lempres: "I would respectfully say there is," cites commodities regulation.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Georgia Rep. David Scott: ”It seems to me there is some kind of regulatory shortfall here."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Huizenga: "There is no doubt that a token is not gold, and not a commodity as such."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "There is an important distinction between what is a security and what is a commodity."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "We are waiting for the dust to settle between the SEC and CFTC before we start supporting ICOs."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Lempres: "We do not support any initial coin offerings ... because we're not sure what the current regulatory" structure is.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum: “The capacity of artificial intelligence to combine with the blockchain to provide new marketing opportunities … is tremendous," but can also enable fraud, and this is hard to predict right now.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Huizenga: "This panel, this Congress is not going to sit by idly with a lack of protection for investors."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer: "The rules are in place, but it's a mish-mash."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Huizenga opens questioning by asking Brummer about investor protections. 

Brummer: "There is a regulatory vacuum currently. That regulatory vacuum extends to some extent to the spot market in cryptocurrencies."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh ends his testimony with a warning if the U.S. does not enable innovation: "We could cede leadership to the rest of the world."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "Scarce tokens are effectively digital commodities ... promises of future tokens are securities."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Van Valkenburgh: "Now these blockchains are just records," but they do not rely on corporations, but rather open networks of servers.
#ICOsInTheHouse

Coin Center Director of Research Peter Van Valkenburgh is now speaking: "The fundamental innovation of bitcoin is digital scarcity."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum also believes it is "premature to craft [legislation] ... but there are basic principles that could inform that legislation when you're able to get to it."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Rosenblum has two suggestions for Congress: The first is allow the SEC and CFTC to modify their rules "to better assist ICO marketers in meeting the federal securities laws."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Robert Rosemblum, a partner with Wilson, Sonsini, Goodrich & Rosati, is now opening his testimony: "I think there really are some very important things happening in this market and that's why it's so important for the subcommittee to focus on these issues." 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Brummer is outlining how disclosure laws and regulations could be updated to guide ICO white papers. 
#ICOsInTheHouse

Georgetown Law Professor Chris Brummer is now testifying: "Evidence of fraud is rife in many ICOs, necessitating welcome responses by regulators, but an awareness of the need for better policing of these markets is not in itself sufficiently instructive."
#ICOsInTheHouse

Schweikert says the difficult part is explaining the technology to his colleagues: "I don't need [Congress] to understand what a node network is ... I'm trying to sell the societal good." 
#DCBlockchain

Schweikert: "That's where I'm most worried about the regulatory world, because they're going to want to slow this down and say 'I need 24 hours to vet this' and they're going to take away all the efficiency." 
#DCBlockchain

Schweikert: "The regulators are all going to want to step in and say 'I want to be the arbitrator so I can reverse a transaction.'" 
#DCBlockchain

Schweikert: "I have a weird fixation on node networks ... for different types of things you might actually reach into a different network."
#DCBlockchain

Schweikert: "Can you image how much easier our lives would be if we could open a vault door and choose what kind of information we need?"
#DCBlockchain

Schweikert on other use cases: "Where are your medical records while you're bleeding out in an emergency room on a Sunday?" 
#DCblockchain

Schweikert says he wishes there was more discussion on tokenization, but that's a "personal" desire 
#DCblockchain

Schweikert: "We don't have to reinvent the wheel from top to bottom. We actually do have case laws and IRS rules that are out there to think about these things." 
#DCBlockchain

Schweikert on taxing cryptocurrencies: "We actually have 100 years of history of 'how do you tax people that do foreign exchanges?'"
#DCblockchain

Schweikert: "We all know that adoption is going to want some guardrails." 
#DCblockchain

Schweikert: "As investors on the crypto side start to become mainstream, I think the mainstream will want to know: 'is it still the wild west?'"
#DCblockchain

Schweikert: "There's so many applications here that if you start to unify the mechanisms, it solves a lot of my societal problems." 
#DCblockchain

The @HouseScience hearing concluded some two hours after it began. The public still has two weeks to submit written statements to the committee. #DLTinDC

Wright: "I think public, open blockchains are the major use case that will emerge and that will serve as the spine, the backbone for a number of different protocols which will change industries." #DLTinDC
Yiannas: "I think the transparency we can give to consumers, the information about where [food] comes from, I think that would be important." #DLTinDC
Cuomo: "We are leaving parts of our digital life all over the place. I think cleaning it up with standards would be [beneficial]." #DLTinDC
Romine: "We're in the beginning stages of building our testbed. If I were a betting man, I would say the winning test is one we haven't thought of yet." #DLTinDC
Jaikaran: "The swath of available projects is very wide at this point ... as we continue to investigate this, we'll determine what might be the most applicable for government use." #DLTinDC
In closing, Abraham asks how the committee can support blockchain research going forward. #DLTinDC
Wright: "Could there be an infinite number of virtual currencies? Theoretically, yes." #DLTinDC
Cuomo: "We’ve enabled systems with ‘right-to-be-forgotten’ by ... marrying two systems. So what is being redacted is not the information - the cookie crumb on the blockchain stays." #DLTinDC
Wright: Digitized fiat currencies on a blockchain are "in the proof-of-concept" in some countries. #DLTinDC
Wright: "In the U.S. obviously the land title record system is fractured and it would take cooperation from agencies to change that but that's the promise." #DLTinDC
Wright and Cuomo both encourage funding projects or prizes to support academic and private research into blockchain projects. #DLTinDC
Wright: "I think blockchain technology - and some have analogized it to being as impactful, if not more impactful, than the internet." #DLTinDC
Wright: "There's a tremendous amount of activity in New York, a tremendous amount of activity in the Bay Area. I think we're on great ground when it comes to innovation occurring here." #DLTinDC
Jaikaran: "[Blockchain] is a potential technology that can be applied to [health records storage] problems. Whether or not it solves it depends on that specific application." #DLTinDC
Yiannas: "We are going to try and design a system for food safety specific to farmers' needs." #DLTinDC
Jaikaran on blockchain-based voting systems: "The blockchain doesn’t record the vote, it records the person, the identity, voting. The vote itself is stored on another secure system." #DLTinDC
Saudi Central Bank to Test Ripple Payments Tech https://t.co/6sMbFVpy3S https://t.co/spOuOOlcqP

In response to a question from Perlmutter, Romine reiterates that quantum computing is some time away from breaking cryptography, which NIST and other government agencies have used prior to blockchain's development. #DLTinDC
Rep. Ed Perlmutter: "The possibilities are endless [for blockchain]." #DLTinDC
Both Yiannas and Cuomo agreed with Rep. Jim Banks' statement that private industry has benefited from light regulation in the blockchain space. #DLTinDC
Cuomo: "There’s an immense amount of innovation that will happen using blockchain." #DLTinDC

In response to a question from Rep. Clay Higgins, Romine notes that quantum computing is 15-30 years from being "crypotgraphically relevant," meaning it will be at least that long before it can compromise public blockchains. #DLTinDC

Jaikaran: "For some of the more sensitive supply-chain concerns, the implementation may be permissioned and private, meaning not everyone can access that blockchain, and even those who do cannot access all of it." #DLTinDC

Wright further explains his proposed blockchain commission: "There's competing interpretations [on blockchain tools] that have been issued already by federal agencies, so the thought would be to standardize that." #DLTinDC

Cuomo, in response to a question on digital identity on a blockchain: "One of the misnomers about using a blockchain to store personal identity is the idea that you put personal information on the ledger - you don’t. You put it on a routing system." #DLTinDC

Beyer asks whether an electro-magnetic pulse would destroy a blockchain ledger. 

Romine: "That's certainly one catastrophic scenario which could jeopardize the technology but otherwise it would be difficult [to disrupt a blockchain]." 
#DLTinDC
Abraham's first question revolves around blockchain's immutability: "How is it tamper-proof?" #DLTinDC
Abraham: “If I’m understanding this correctly, this technology could be transformational.” #DLTinDC
Wright: "I would encourage Congress to commission a blockchain advisory group [to study the technology and regulations]." #DLTinDC
US Treasury Official Calls for Global Crypto Regulation https://t.co/W2yW4jIIea https://t.co/1OKEm0ROK1
Aaron Wright, a law professor who focuses on technology law: "Token sales can prove a potent form of democratizing access to capital." #DLTinDC

Walmart's Frank Yiannas: "In 2017 Walmart decided to trial a blockchain to track mangoes from store to store ... at the end of the trial, we proved we could cut down the time to trace food from seven days to 2.2 seconds." #DLTinDC
Cuomo: "We urge Congress and the Trump administration, when considering regulatory frameworks, to note the difference between currency uses and broader applications of blockchain." #DLTinDC
The third witness, IBM's Jerry Cuomo, references existing and past projects, calling out a recent joint venture with Maersk. Missed it? Read about it here: https://t.co/wG7YYXIpH3 #DLTinDC
Romine: "When the news media reports that bitcoin was stolen, it almost certainly means that the private keys were found, not that the system was compromised." #DLTinDC
Charles H. Romine, director, Information Technology Laboratory, National Institute of Standards and Technology is explaining how private keys secure assets on a blockchain. #DLTinDC

The first witness, Chris A. Jaikaran, analyst in cybersecurity policy, Government and Finance Division, Congressional Research Service: "An advantage to blockchain emerges when looking for a undeniable, traceable ledger." #DLTinDC
Rep. Barbara Comstock: "[Blockchain] aplications have potential benefits for the federal government."  #DLTinDC
Beyer: "I'm specifically interested in what you have to say in the steps [witnesses] say we should be taking in making us the hub of blockchain technology." #DLTinDC
Rep. Don Beyer is now making his opening statement: "I've just come back from the World Economic Forum where it seemed every other panel was about blockchain." #DLTinDC
